There are several geographic features in North America that affect rainfall patterns. These include:

1. Mountain ranges: When moist air from the ocean encounters a mountain range, it is forced to rise, cool, and condense into rain or snow. This is known as orographic precipitation. In North America, the Rocky Mountains, Sierra Nevada, and Appalachian Mountains all create varying rainfall patterns. Areas on the windward side of the mountains tend to receive more precipitation than areas on the leeward side.

2. Coastlines: Coastal areas tend to receive more rainfall than inland areas. This is because sea breezes bring moisture and cooler air inland, which can result in increased rainfall. The Gulf of Mexico, for example, contributes to high levels of rainfall in the southeastern United States.

3. Deserts: Areas with desert climates, such as the Mojave Desert and Sonoran Desert, tend to have low levels of rainfall. This is because moisture is blocked by mountain ranges and dry air prevails. Flora and fauna in these areas have adapted to survive in low rainfall conditions.

The rainfall patterns created by these geographic features have a significant impact on the flora and fauna of certain areas. Areas with high levels of rainfall tend to have more diverse plant and animal life, as well as larger and more productive ecosystems. Areas with low rainfall, on the other hand, tend to have a more limited range of plant and animal species, with adaptations for water conservation and drought resistance. Desert plants, for example, have evolved to store water and have shallow roots to absorb rainwater quickly. Similarly, animals in these areas are often adapted to conserve water, such as by burrowing underground or being active at night when temperatures are cooler. Overall, rainfall patterns play a critical role in shaping the natural environment in North America.
